column1: This area was occupied for thousands of years by succeeding cultures of indigenous peoples. The historic Ojibwe (also known in the United States as the Chippewa) occupied it in the period of European encounter. They had a lucrative fur trade for decades with French colonists and French Canadians.  After the French and Indian War this trade was dominated by British-American trappers from the eastern seaboard.

The Wisconsin River first drew European-American settlers to the area during the mid-19th century as they migrated west into the Great Lakes region following construction of the Erie Canal in New York State. This provided a route for products from the region to the large New York and other eastern markets. The area had been called "Big Bull Flats" or "Big Bull Falls" by French explorers
column2: who were the first Europeans here. They named it for the long rapids in the river
column3: which created many bubbles
column4: called bulle in French. By an 1836 treaty with the United States
column5: the Ojibwe ceded much of their lands in the area to federal ownership. It was sold to non-Native peoples. Wausau
column7: means "a faraway place" or "a place from which one can see far away".

column2: the namesake of the city of Stevens Point south of Wausau
column3: began harvesting the pine forests for lumber in 1840 and built a saw mill. Lumbering was the first major industry in this area
column4: and other sawmills along the Wisconsin River were quickly constructed by entrepreneurs. By 1846
column5: Walter McIndoe arrived and took the lead in the local business and community. His efforts helped to establish Marathon County in 1850. Word of Stevens's success in the region spread across the country throughout the logging industry.  Loggers came from Cortland County
column7: Carroll County
column10: Vermont and Down East Maine in what is now Washington County
column13: descended from the English Puritans who settled New England during the 1600s.

column2: Wausau had been established as a town and continued to grow and mature. German immigration into the area following the Revolutions of 1848 in the German states brought more people
column3: and by 1861
column4: the settlement was incorporated as a village.Churches
column6: industry and social organizations began to flourish. The state granted the city a charter in 1872
column7: and elections are held the first Tuesday in April. The residents elected August Kickbusch as their first mayor in 1874. Five years earlier
column8: Kickbusch had returned to his homeland of Germany and brought back with him 702 people
column9: all of whom are believed to have settled in the Wausau area. Kickbusch founded the A. Kickbusch Wholesale Grocery Company
column10: a family business carried on by his grandson
column12: August Kickbusch II purchased a modest four-square-style house at 513 Grant Street. He undertook extensive additions
column15: a tiled porch in the Mediterranean style
column17: and ornate custom-designed chimney crowns. The home is on the National Register of Historic Places as part of the Andrew Warren Historic District.

column2: Wausau became more accessible to settlers and industry. This enabled the city to develop alternatives to the lumber industry
column3: which was in decline since the clear-cutting of many forests. By 1906 the lumber was gone
column4: but the city continued to grow and flourish. Other villages and towns in the area declined because of over-harvesting of the forests and lumber mills closed down.

column1: Wausau's favorable location on the Wisconsin River was partly responsible for its survival. The economy was diversified in the early 20th century
column2: led by Employers Insurance of Wausau
column3: now a part of Liberty Mutual. Its logo
column4: first introduced in 1954
column5: was the downtown Milwaukee Road railroad depot set against the backdrop of the community's skyline.

column1: The Wall Street Crash of 1929 had a major effect on the Wausau area. Many industries were forced to cut back by laying off and dismissing workers or by closing altogether. After decades of growth
column2: the city virtually ground to a halt. But under the New Deal
column3: Wausau was significantly modernized. After World War II
column4: it continued to grow in industry

column2: Hmong refugees from Southeast Asia who fought alongside the CIA immigrated to Wausau at the end of the 1970s. Wausau church organizations (Catholic and Lutheran) helped Hmong refugees adapt to American life.
the Wausau Center shopping mall opened. By the mid- to late 1990s

column1: Wausau's climate is classified as humid continental (Dfb). It is built on or around a hemiboreal forest
column2: which has some of the characteristics of a boreal forest and shares some of the features of the temperate zone forests to the south. Coniferous trees predominate in the hemiboreal zone
column3: but a significant number of deciduous species are found there
column4: as well.

column1: As of 2003 the Hmong Americans are the largest ethnic minority in Wausau. Churches and social service agencies settled refugees
column2: most of them Hmong with some Vietnamese and Lao
column3: in Wausau after the Vietnam War. According to the 1980 U.S. Census
column4: the Wausau SMSA had fewer than 1% non-White people. There were several dozen immigrants in 1978. By 1980 Wausau had 200 immigrants. This increased to 400 in 1982 and 800 in 1984.In 1981 there were 160 Hmong students in the Wausau School District and in 1991 1
column5: 010. In a period ending in 1994 the tax rate of the Wausau School District rose by 10.48% as a result of the expenses of services to children from immigrant families. The increase was three times as high as the increase in an adjacent school district without a large immigrant population. By 1994 Wausau had 4
column6: 200 refugees. By 1996 the number of Hmong students in the school district was over 2
column7: 000. In 1998 this number reached its peak
column9: 214. The city experienced some social upheaval following the Hmong arrival. Some schools in Wausau had a minority of English speakers and some were predominantly Hmong students. Some native-born American families in Wausau criticized the crime and expenses in social services.As of 2003
column10: "Sixty percent of Hmong families are homeowners. Although more than half of the workforce is earning less than $8 an hour
column11: the welfare rate has dropped to less than 5 percent. More people are going to college. And test scores and graduation rates of Hmong public school students are steadily rising."In Wausau there is relatively little Hmong-language media because for much of its history
column12: the Hmong language was not written.

column1: Nearly one-third of the Marathon County economy is based in manufacturing

column1: The Wisconsin Woodchucks baseball team of the Northwoods League
column2: an NCAA summer baseball league
column3: plays home games at the Athletic Park in Wausau. The Wisconsin Woodchucks were formerly known as the Wausau Woodchucks. Woody Woodchuck is the mascot of the Woodchucks.

column1: The Wausau River Hawks baseball team of the Dairyland League
column2: a Wisconsin Baseball Association summer baseball league
column3: plays home games at Athletic Park in Wausau. The Wausau River Hawks were formerly known as Wausau Precision.Granite Peak Ski Area offers downhill skiing at nearby Rib Mountain. The 700-ft mountain is the highest skiable mountain in the state and one of the highest vertical drops in the Midwest. It first became a ski area in 1937
column4: when Wausau residents cleared six runs by hand
column5: installed the nation's longest ski lift
column6: and built a chalet with stone quarried nearby. Granite Peak has 74 runs and seven ski lifts. Granite Peak earned Ski Magazine's #1 ranking in Wisconsin
column7: Upper Michigan and Minnesota.Wausau hosts the annual Badger State Winter Games.
